It will thus be seen that the object had in view is the public weal, and that if we are restrained of any portion of our accustomed rights, it is done for our own good, as well as for the general safety.
This consideration alone should reconcile as to any inconveniences that may result from the establishment of martial law.

It is proper to remark, however, that in the execution of martial law great prudence is to be exercised.
Chief Justice Taney holds "that no more force can be used than is necessary, and if the power be used for oppression, or any willful injury be done to person or property, the party by whom or whose order it is done, will be responsible to the injured person."

A review of the legal authorities would seem to conduct to the conclusion, that a military officer cannot declare martial law except over his own camp and its environs, and the near field of his military operations.
Such was the opinion of Judge Woodbury, who said:

q.p: "My impression is, that a state of war, whether foreign or domestic, may enlist in the great peril of which it is competent under its rights and on principles of national law, for the commanding officer of troops, under the controlling government to extend certain right of war not only over his camp, but its environs, and the near field of his military operations, but no further or wider."

div3.p:
The best opinion would seem to be that in time of war, the Government, by act of Congress, may place the country under martial law in a limited and mitigated sense; though there has been much controversy upon the limitation of the power.
So also, in the language of Judge Woodbury, the commanding officer of troops may "extend certain rights of war, not only over his camp, but the environs and the near field of his military operations." Beyond this, neither the Government nor the military commander can properly go.

Nothing but imminent peril to the army, arising from the near presence of the army, can authorize the commander to suspend or arrest the execution of ordinary civil process.
In this, as in other respects, the safety of the army will be the ruling motive of the military commander.

There are but two instances in which martial law was resorted to under the old Government.
The first was in New Orleans, in 1862, when Gen. Jackson took the authority, against the opinion of Edward Livingston, one of the ablest jurists of his day to place that city under martial law. The second was in 1862, and occurred in Rhode Island during what is known as the Dorr rebellion.

div3.head:
Camp of 2nd Co., Howitzers,
near Yorktown, March 13th, 1862.
div3.p: The 2ND Co. Richmond Howitzers, having heard with deep regret of the death of their beloved fellow soldier, Thomas Pollard, Jr. Therefore,

Resolved, That while it behooves us to submit with calm resignation to the will of Almighty God, yet we deeply feel the loss we have sustained in the death of our late comrade-in-arms--one of the first who sprang to the rescue of his country, and one of the most devoted to our common cause.
Endeared to all who knew him by his many noble qualities, may he have left his earthly, friends to find far better ones in Heaven.
Resolved. That a copy of these proceedings be published in the Richmond Whig and Daily Dispatch, and that a copy be sent to the family of the deceased.
div3.closer:
Capt. Henry Hudnall, Ch'n Lieut.
Lewis Booker, Sec'y.
Whig copy. mh 25--it*

div3.head: To the voters of the city of Richmond.
div3.p: --I hereby announce myself a candidate for the Captaincy of the night Watch, and solicit your votes, Election, 2d day of April.

div3.head: Captain of the city night police.
div3.p: --I am a candidate for the office of Captain of the city night Watch at the ensuing election, and pledge myself to the voters of the city that, if elected, the duties of the office shall be promptly and efficiently discharged.

div4.p: --Northern papers to the 22d have been received at the office of the Day Book
It is stated at the North that Hon. Wm. L. Yancey had certainly been captured, off Key West, by the Water Witch; but a dispatch from Nashville announces his arrival at New Orleans.
It is rumored that the Rebels at Island Note have been seriously damaged by fire from mortars thrown from the Federal gunboats, and that they are preparing to evacuate.

--The Tex bill is still dragging its slow length along.
The whiskey insurrection kept the house occupied all day. It is supposed the bill will be crowded through the House in three weeks.
Fremont leaves for his new department to-day.
The steamer Roanoke is to be iron-clad.
Nothing official from the West.
Senator Wade's friends are confident of his election to the U. S. Senate.
Information has been received at Washington that large quantities of cotton had been taken through Texas, and thence to Europe.

--Jeff. Thompson is marching upon Cape Girardeau, and is pressing men and horses into the rebel service — A skirmish has taken place between some of his forces and the Federals, in which several were killed and wounded on both sides.

--United States 6's, 1881, 941.
Sales of cotton have been made at Philadelphia at 18, 31 for low and high grades — firmer.
The name of Fort Calhoun is to be changed to that of Fort Wool.
General Wool has established a Sansorship over the press in his division.
A large number of troops were landed at Fortress Monroe and Camp Hamilton yesterday, and to-day there is great activity at Old Point.

Advices have been received here (Norfolk) from Newbern, which state that four hundred Confederates have recently had a fight with the Yankees, in which fifteen hundred of the latter were killed.
The Federals raised the white flag twice during the battle, but the Confederates were prevented from seeing it on account of the smoke.

The Northern account says the Confederates had thirteen hundred in the field, and that it was a hard fight.
The Yankees, according to their own account suffered severely, and lost many of their best officers.
Five hundred Confederates are reported (by the Yankees) to have been taken prisoners, together with fifty pieces of cannon and large quantities of arms and ammunition.

The Yankee troops at Newbern are in good quarters.
The Confederates fired the town and railroad bridge.
But one hundred of the old white population remain.
There were but three stores open.
There are no tidings of the frigate Vermont.
It is positively seretted in the Northern papers that Captain Buchanan, of the "Virginia," died in this city (Norfolk) on Sunday; but the honored hero of Newport News is recovering.

There was heavy cannonading upon Island No.10 from the Federal mortar boats all day Wednesday, the 19th inst., doing much damage.
It is supposed the Confederates are evacuating the island (Doubtful) The fire was Returned vigorously from the Confederate batteries.

div3.head: Movements in Hampton Roads.
div3.p:
--Twenty Federal transport steamers entered the Roads last evening.
All excepting one were painted white, and all crowded with troops.
They apparently came across the Bay, from the direction of the Eastern Shore.
It is supposed that they are intended to reinforce Burnside or attack Magruder.
Between ninety and a hundred steamers and sailing vessels were in the Roads yesterday.

div3.head: Ranaway.
div3.p:
--$50 Reward — Ranaway, from my farm in Henrico co., on the night of the 23d inst., four negro men, to with Isham, Abram, Jack and Pleasants.
Isham is an old man, about 55 years old; when spoken to looks down — Abram is a tall, brown mulatto, aged 25 years--Jack is 45 years old, and has one leg very much swollen — Pleasants, aged 20 years, stammers when spoken to I will give the above reward for the delivery of said negroes or secured in any jail so I can get them, or $12.50 for each

div3.head: Fifty Dollars Reward
div3.p:
--Will be paid for the arrest and delivery to me of my negro man Abram, if taken outside the city or county, and $25 if within.
He will doubtless try to go to Fredericksburg on the railroad track.
He is 29 years old; black; heavy build; 5 feet 8 or 10 inches high; had on light colored full cloth clothes; heavy brogans.
He was brought from King George county, Va., on Monday last.
div3.closer:
W. Colton,
Monument Hotel. mh 25--1w*

div3.head: Battalion of Cavalry
div3.p:
--In the month of February I received authority from the Secretary of War to raise a battalion or regiment of Cavalry.
I have hesitated to undertake to do so until this time and I now propose to raise a Battalion of Cavalry, if it can be done without absenting myself too much from my present command.

Persons desisting to unite with me in this patriotic effort, and those wishing authority to recruit and raise companies, will address me at this place, or, what is still better, report in person at once.
I expect to have two companies of infantry and one of artillery attached to my command.
Call for the present at Messrs. Yarbrough's, south side of Main street, three doors above 7th, or at my company quarters, New Fair Grounds.

closer.signed: Capt. Comd'g Cavalry Co. P. A. C. S.

div3.head:
Attention,
Otey Battery.
div3.p:
--Meet this Morning at the Rendezvous, 13 Pearl street, at 9 o'clock, Knapsacks, &c., will be ready.
Members are advised to prepare themselves with--
2 woolen Overshirts;
2 Overshirts, colored;
2 pair good Drawers;
2 pair woolen Socks,
1 pair Shoes or Boots — only one pair;
2 silk Handkerchiefs;
2 Towels; Tin Plate; Tin Cup, (handle riveted on;) Knife and Fork, Comb, Needles, Buttons, &c., piece of Oil Cloth, or Oil Cloth Blanket.
The company will go into camp Wednesday morning, and will report for duty at the Rendezvous at 10 o'clock, without farther orders.
div3.closer:
By order of Capt. G. G. Otey.
W. G. Miller,
2d Sergeant. mh 26--2t*

div3.head: Twenty-five Dollars Reward.
div3.p: I will pay $25 reward each for the apprehension and delivery to me, at Camp Lee, of Robert Burton and John M. Travers, who have deserted from my Company

Robert Burton is 31 years of age, about 5 feet 11 inches high, has auburn hair, gray eyes, and ruddy complexion — has the letters R. B. printed on the back of the left hand, and generally wears his hair and moustache dyed black.
John M. Travers is 22 years of age, 5 feet 6 inches high, has dark complexion, gray eyes, black hair, and is a printer by profession.
All members of my company now absent from camp, without permission, will report to me without delay, or they will be advertised and treated as deserters

div3.head: Deserters.
div3.p:
--The following named men, having deserted from my company during the past week.
I will give the reward affixed to their names if delivered to me at my office, on Bank street between 9th and 10th streets:
The police and guard are requested to use every exertion to arrest the above named men.

Lieut, and Recruiting Officer
Richmond Sharp Shooters,
Bank, betw 9th and 10th sts. mh 25--2t*

div3.head: Flying Artillery.
div3.p: We are authorized to raise a company of Flying Artillery, to be composed of young men between the ages of sixteen and eighteen and to be attached to Major Archer's Tredegar (Eighth) Battalion Virginia Volunteers.
The guns we propose to use can be seen at the Tredegar Works.
Each member will be expected to provide himself with a cheap uniform.
div3.closer:
J. F. Goodwis.
Jno. E. Tanner.
Tredegar Iron Works, Richmond Mar. 24, 1862. mh 25--ts

div3.head: The Manchester Artillery.
div3.p:
I will be in Manchester until Monday, 31st inst., for the purpose of obtaining.
Recruits for this Company, stationed at present at Sewell's Point Battery, Norfolk harbor.
All desirous of joining a good company, which has seen service, can communicate with me at my store in Manchester.
Recruits will be entitled to the usual bounty of $50 and pay for clothing.

div3.head: Light Artillery.
div3.p: --I am authorized by the Governor of Virginia to raise a Company of Light Artillery for the war. All those desirous of enlisting in this the most effective arm of the service, would do well to call at once at the office of Johnson & Guigon, Whig Building.
Uniforms and subsistence furnished.

div3.head:
Attention.
wise Mounted Guard!
div3.p:
The members of this company will-report themselves at Camp Howard's Grove, on Thursday, at 10 o'clock A. M., for the purpose of being mustered into service.
Every member of this company is expected to be punctual in attendance.

div3.head: Attention, Recruits!
div3.p: All Recruits in the Thomas Artillery will report at once at the office on 12th street, or be arrested and punished as deserters.

div3.head: A fine Chance for young men.
div3.p:
Wanted — A First and Junior Second Lieutenant for a company of Heavy Artillery, now being organised by authority of the Secretary of War.
Address "Artillery," at this office, or box 1,220 city Post Office.
Attention, Volunteers!
Battery secured.

The undersigned, having secured A splendid Battery of field-pieces, have authority to raise a company of Light Artillery, to be mustered in the Provisional Army of Virginia for the war, and have received authority from the Governor to recruit volunteers from the militia, to fill the ranks of the Crutchfield Light Artillery.
The company will be mustered in as soon as a sufficient number of volunteers have been received.
A fine opportunity now presents itself to those who do not wish to go as militiamen, to enroll themselves as volunteers.
No substitutes received.
Apply at the office of the Old Dominion Insurance Company, under the St Charles Hotel.

div3.head:
Howitzer and Rifle
Light Battery.

Light Artillery service,

and I have secured a splendid Battery of
Howitzers,
and wrought iron breach loading
Rifle guns,
of the meet approved patents.
This is the most effective, popular, and distinguished arm of the service.
The Battery will be fully

Mounted and
Equipped.
A Bounty of
Fifty Dollars
allowed to each recruit, and
Thirty Dollars
by the city of Petersburg.
Apply at once.
div3.closer:

Capt. C. K. 6th Reg't Va. Vols.
Craney Island, near Norfolk, Va.

J. R. B. [mh 24--12t]

div3.head:
Bossieux's Artillery--
Camp Winder.
div3.p:
I am diestrous of obtaining my full complement of men. It will take twenty-five more than I now have to do this.
I have now nearly one hundred.
None but good men will be accepted.
No substitutes taken.
For full particulars, apply at No. 80 Main street, or at Camp Winder.

Camp Lee, March 21, 1862

This Company will receive thirty recruits to complete its quota.
Persons wishing to join this branch of service will do will to apply immediately, as opportunities are limited.
A splendid battery secured.
Office on 10th street, or at New Fair Grounds.

All persons desirous of joining this time-honored company, will apply promptly at the recruiting office, on 12th street, between Main and Bank.

--All who wish to go into service under favorable auspices can do so by applying at Charles Bunt's "Our House," or at the rendezvous, on 10th street, next to Crawford's Saloon.--Fifty dollars bounty and perquisites.
This is to be a Heavy Artillery company.

Any proceedings taken by the authorities of the State of Virginia for the collection of the public revenue are hereby exempted from the operation of General Order, No. 9, 11, and 18, A & I. G. O. of March st, 8th, and 14th, declaring martial law."

div3.head:
Co. "B," 1st Va, Vols.
Richmond, March 21st, 1862.
div3.p:
Company "B," 1ST Reg't Va. Vols., having re-enlisted for the war, wants a few more Recruits, to fill up its ranks.
Will not the young men of Richmond come forward and enlist in one of the oldest companies in the oldest regiment in the Confederate States? $50 bounty paid.
Call at No. 8, 10th street, between main and Caly.

div3.head:
Attention!
Teamsters.
div3.p:
I wish to enlist ten or twelve good Drivers for my battery.
To experienced men I will give $25, in addition to the Government bounty of $50, Persons wishing to enlist will please call on me without delay, at Camp Let near this city.

div3.head:
Jeff.
Davis Battery.
div3.p:
Twenty men wanted to complete the organization.
$50 bounty.
Call on J. T Rogers, corner Main and 6th streets; Sampson Jones, corner Main and 9th streets; or at the Rendezvous, on 10th, between Main and Bank sts.

div3.head: Heavy Artillery.
div3.p: $50 Bounty, and
Uniforms furnished.

The undersigned are authorized by the Secretary of War to raise a Company for the heavy Artillery service.
We have been for the past eleven months in active service as Lieutenants of such a company, and have already a number of men enlisted.
All who desire to join us will please apply at our recruiting office, No. 17, Main street, up stairs, to Wm. Lawson, Company H, First Regiment Virginia Volunteers; or at our Camp in Yorktown.

div3.head: Recruits wanted for an Infirmary Company.
div3.p:
--Having obtained from the Secretary of War authority to organize an Infirmary Company, to go into the active service of the Confederate States for the war, I respectfully call upon all persons subject to militia duty to enlist in this new branch of the service.
This company's duties will be to attend the wounded soldiers on a field of battle, and so prevent them from bleeding to death.
The company will be stationed a short distance in the rear of the line of battle, to immediately dress the wounds of each soldier wounded and remove him from the field to some proper hospital.
Each man enlisting will receive the bounty of $50. Uniforms and equipments also furnished Having nearly my complement of men, I should like to receive about 30 more good recruits.
Apply soon at my recruiting office, Broad street, between 6th and 7th streets.

div3.head: Militia, attention
div3.p: --I am authorized by the Secretary of War to raise a Company of Heavy Artillery, to be attached to Morriss's Battalion.
The usual bounty of $50 will be paid when the roll is signed and the volunteer sworn in.
Call at P. H. Starke's, Main, between 14th and 15th streets, for the present.
Any militiaman can come in sign the roll, take the bounty, and be exempt.

div3.head: Notice
div3.p:
--The Second Company of Richmond Howitzers has been reorganized, and Lieutenant David Watson elected Captain.
We are anxious to increase the number of our Company to 120 An opportunity is thus offered to young men of good moral character to join an old organization, which has two rifles and two howitzers, and is thoroughly equipped for field service

Apply to R. B. Pleasants or Henry S. Jones, No. 7, Wall street, under St. Charles Hotel; or Wm. N. Wellford, Jr', Brandy Station, Culpeper county, Virginia, or Geo. L. Christian, Charles City C. H., Virginia.

--A few more men are wanted for this company to complete it to the maximum.--By command.
I am authorized to recruit men for three years or the war from militia companies called out by the proclamation the Governor of Virginia, and who are an enrolled and in camp.
Under this authorize I appeal to the patriotism of all true men to rally to the standard of the Richmond Cayette Artillery.
Apply immediately G. W. Winston Jones, Jr., or Peyton Johnston, 115 Main street, Richmond.
div3.closer:
miles C. Macon,
Captain.
N. B — The bounty of $50 given. mh 20--1w

commanded by Officers

div4.head: Colonel Godwin's regiment.
div4.p: --We are authorized to raise a regiment of infantry, to be stationed near Portsmouth; and we have the assurance of the Secretary of War that the regiment will be Capt near Portsmouth as long as any troops are required for its defence.
We are happy to state that we have every prospect of the early completion of the regiment.
We have established, for the present our rendezvous at the winter quarter lately occupied by the Third George's regiment, situated near Portsmouth.

Volunteers and recruits will be received at our rendezvous by companies, squads, or clingy, and they will be forthwith mustered into service, and be entitled to pay, subsistence &c., from the time of their being mustered in. Persons raising companies for our regiment may advantageously make our rendezvous the headquarters for their recruits.

Companies now in service can re-enlist for our regiment by having it go designated by the mustering officer on their muster rolls when they re-enlist; and they will be transferred at the capitation of the present term of their enlistment from their present regiment to ours.

Individuals in any company, now in service, can re-enlist for our regiment by having it designated on their muster rolls at the time of their re-enlistment, and they will be transferred from their present companies and regiments to our regiment on the expiration of their present term of enlistment.
Re-enlisted men re-enlisting for our regiment will be entitled to join together and organize themselves into companies, and to elect their company officers.
All persons wishing to re-enlist for our regiment must re-enlist under the Confederate law.
Persons volunteering or re-enlisting for our regiment will be entitled to the bounty and furlough provided for by law.

Organized companies, or re-enlisted men in any numbers, will be mustered in for our regiment at any time, by application to the proper mustering officer, or to Lieut. Col. J. F. Crocker, who will attend to their being mustered in.

Lieut.-Col. Crocker will superintend the rendezvous at the winter quarters lately occupied by the Third Georgia regiment, and he will be found there or at the Macon Hotel, Portsmouth, at any time.
He will give any information required, and will receive recruits and make immediate provision for them.
All communications addressed to Colonel D. J. Godwin, Suffolk, Va., 14th Regiment Virginia Volunteers, or to Lieut. Col. J. F. Crocker, Portsmouth, will be promptly attended to.
div4.closer:
D. J. Godwin,
J. F. Crocker.
Portsmouth, March 5, 1862.

dateline.name: Confederate States of America, War Department, Richmond,

div4.p:
I have commented, at the request of the Legislature of Virginia, to accept no more additional companies, battalions, or regiments of volunteers in Virginia, until after the quota of the State has been furnished for the war out this does not in any manner interfere with authority previously granted to raise companies, battalions or regiments within the State of Virginia.
Any companies, therefore which may have been, or may be, railed or organized under the authority granted Lieut. Col. Goodwin to raise a regiment for the war, will be accepted, and may be mustered into service in conformity with the terms of that authority.

div3.head:
Recruits--
Richmond Sharp Shooters.
div3.p:
Fifty Recruits are wanted to fill up the ranks of this well known company to the maximum number.
A bounty of $50 will be paid each recruit, and sustenance commuted until they join the company; pay commences from date of enlistment.
None but good men need apply, as the company heretofore has sustained an enviable reputation.

This company is armed with good Rifles, and has seen as much active service as any company in the army.
Application to be made to the undersigned at Star Exchange. Bank street, or to Corporal.

div3.head: Maryland Battalion.
div3.p: The undersigned has been authorized to organize a Battalion of Infantry, to form part of the Maryland Lind

Under an act of Congress, approved February 15, 1862, any native or adopted citizen of Maryland may, upon his own application, be transferred at once to the Maryland Line.
Or any company composed of citizens of Maryland or the District of Columbia may, upon application, be so transferred.
Individuals or companies desirous of joining this Battalion, will apply in person at the office of Weston & Williams, No. 15 Pearl street, or by mail to

div3.head: Attention — Boggs's Battalion Flying Artillery.
div3.p:
The undersigned having authority to raise a Company, to form a part of this splendid corps, for which the most approved light rifled pieces are now being turned out, all those wishing to join a select company, and avoid the militia, will do well to control themselves at once, as the ranks are filling rapidly.
The special attention of the militia is invited to the fact that we are authorized to give the most positive assurance that no man enlisting in this company remains liable either to the present call of the Governor, or to any future draft upon the militia.
Who will wait to be a drafted militiaman!
Apply at the Recruiting Office of the Battalion, Bank street, near the corner of 12th
Bounty down--fifty dollars.
We refer particularly to Major Boggs's card, calling on those who wish to enter his corps to report to the officers of this company
div3.closer:

1st Company Howitzers.
Alex'r Q Holladay,

Fayette Artillery.
Richard M. Bolling.
Goochland Light Dragoons.

div3.head:
Fifty Dollars bounty.
attention, Volunteers!
stationary Battery.
Heavy Artillery.
div3.p: Lieut. J. Hatley Norton, of the Naval Battery during the past year, having been duty authorized by the Secretary of War, with the approbation and approval of Major General Magruder, to raise and organize a company, of 125 men, for the Yorktown Naval Battery, hereby offers an opportunity to healthy, able-bodied, courageous men, to enlist in the cause of their country, and in one of the best locations in the Southern States.

This celebrated Battery is now completed and the prospects of a speedy advance of the enemy to this point at the opening of the Spring campaign, renders it necessary that this company should be filled up at as early a day as possible and should allege an inducement to all those having their country's interest at heart, to hasten to her aid and to be found at a post where they can render her the most efficient service.
As soon as the exigencies of the case will permit, furious to all re-enlisted men will be granted regularly, and a certain number may be absent from the company at stated times.
div3.closer:
Apply to Lieut, Norton
At Duval Drug Store, Richmond, or at the Naval Battery, Yorktown, mh 19--6t*

figure.figDesc: Page image of Daily Dispatch, Volume 21, Number 71, page 4.

div3.head:
The old grenadier's story.
told on a Bench outside the Invalids.
by G. W. Yeorebury.

lg.l: T'was the day beside the Pyramids,
It seems but an hour ago,
That Kleber's foot stood firm in squares,
Returning blow for blow.
The Mamelukes were to saing
Their standards to the sky,
When I heard a child's voice say, "My men,
Teach me the way to die!"
T'was a little drummer, with his side
Torn terribly with shot;
But still he feebly beat his drum,
As though the wound were not.
And when the Mameluke's wild horse,
Burst with a scream and cry,
He said, "Oh, men of the Forty-third,
Teach me the way to die!
"My mother has got other sons,
With stouter hearts than mine,
But none more ready blood for France
To pour out free as wine.
Yet still life's sweet," the brave lad moaned,
"Fair are this earth and sky;
Then, comrades of the Forty-third,
Teach me the way to die!"
I saw Selenche, of the granite heart,
Wiping his burning eyes--
It was, indeed, more pitiful
Than more loud sobs, and cries.
One bit his cartridge till his lip
Grew black as wintry sky.
But still the boy moaned, "Forty-third,
Teach me the way to die!"
Then never saw I sight like that:
The Sergeant flung down flag,
Even the first bound his brow
With a wet and bloody rag.
They looked at locks and fixed their steel,
But never made reply,
Until he sobbed out once again,
"Teach me the way to die!"
Then with a shout that flew to God,
They strode into the fray;
I saw their red plumes join and wave,
But slowly melt away.
The last who went — a wounded man--
Bade the poor boy good-bye,
And said, "We men of the Forty-third
Teach you the way to die!"
I never saw so sad a look
As the poor youngster cast,
When the hot smoke of cannon
In cloud and whirlwind passed.
Earth shook and heaven answered--
I watched his eagle eye,
As he faintly moaned, "The Forty-third,
Teach me the way to die!"
Then with a musket for a crutch
He limped into the fight;
I, with a bullet in my hip,
Had neither strength nor might.
But, proudly beating on his drum,
A fever in his eye,
I heard him moan, "The Forty-third
Taught me the way to die!"
They found him on the morrow,
Stretched on the heap of dead;
His hand was in the grenadier's
Who at his bidding bled.
They hung a medal round his neck,
And closed his dauntless eye;
On the stone they cut, "The Forty-third
Taught him the way to die!"
'Tis forty years from then till now--
The grave gapes at my feel--
Yet when I think of such a boy,
I feel my old heart bear.
And from my sleep I sometimes wake,
Hearing a feeble cry,
And a voice that says, "The Forty-third
Teach me the way to die!"

opener.salute: To the Editors of the Dispatch:

div4.p:
As I believe you have done much service hitherto in calling attention to the various sources of saltpetre, both in your descriptions of the nitre beds of France and Germany and your notice of the nitrous earths of Southwestern Virginia, I shall venture to say, through your columns, that there is a gentleman in this vicinity who has discovered a mode by which he makes nitre in a very short time; much shorter than that of any of the methods mentioned in your article on nitre beds.
I have seen him scrape off from the sides of a glass vessel, containing a composition less than a week old, fine crystals of nitre, which on burning seemed to me to be exceedingly pure.
Such as this, he says, however, if made in large quantities, would cost forty-five or forty-six cents the pound, owing to artificial heat employed in its production; but, he is confident it can be made by the same method at a cost of only fifteen cents. Tobacco was one of the main ingredients used.
This. I believe, contain some saltpetre in its natural state, but it can very evidently be made to produce much more than it at first contained.
I understand that with a plenty of nitre we may make not only a plenty of gunpowder, but by means of the nitric acid to be obtained from it can make as much gun-cotton as we choose for our torpedoes.
How just and wonderful a dispensation it would be if the tobacco and cotton, which our enemies so much covet, should become not only a source of commercial greatness, but also of military strength, and prove in the hands of Providence the very means of driving the invader from our soil

I understand that the gentleman whose experiments I have taken the liberty to notice in this public manner, has made application for assistance, either to the state or the Confederacy; but with what success, I have not learned.

div3.head: The schooner Beauregard.
div3.p: --We learn from a trustworthy source, that the schr. Beauregard, which left this port on the 5th of November, was captured by the Federal bark W. G. Andrews, Capt. W. G. Rogers, on the 12th of that month, and all on board, numbering twenty-seven, taken prisoners, and conveyed in chains to Key West.

These unfortunate men have endured great suffering and every imaginable indignity during their captivity.
On the passage to Key West they were fed with felon's fare, compelled to remain in a recumbent position, with chains on their hands and feet during the day, and at night were confined in a bread-locker, about six feet square.
The four officers were treated with special roughness.
They were assailed with the most offensive epithets, and annoyed by every means at the command of their brutal enemies.

Since they have been at Key West they have been in rigorous durance, fed on the coarsest food, and watched day and night by heartless and base fellows, who take a fiendish delight in aggravating the miseries of their condition.

Key West is completely under the control of the Lincolnites, and they rule the inhabitants with a rod of iron.
The people have been required to swear allegiance to the Lincoln Government, and so rabid are these slaves of the despot, that they have compelled children eight years old to take the oath.

More than two-thirds of the population are with the South, but they dare not give expression to their sentiments.
Those who were bold enough to give utterance to the feelings of their hearts have been seized and dragged to prison.

There are twenty vessels of war lying at this port, and three thousand five hundred men stationed on the island.
The soldiers are represented to be the sorriest looking creatures that ever disgraced a military uniform.
They are coarse, vicious, and ignorant, and so brave and generous as to insult women, steal whatever they fancy, and destroy furniture.
There is always a strong police force at the post-office, who examine every letter, paper, and package before it is dropped into the mail.--Charleston Courier.

div3.head: A Jermain.
div3.p:
--Abraham the First, King of the Yankees, must have a very fender heart, as well as an immense supply of Ischrymal matter, otherwise we should not so often be saddened by reports of his tearful lamentations.
When Colonel Ellisworth was killed in Alexandria, Lincoln, we were told, shed tears freely, and wrung his hands in bitter anguish; when Gen. Baker felt, at Leesburg, he was almost inconsolable; but when the commander of the iron-clad steamer Monitor, which had the fight in Hampton Roads with the Virginia, was introduced to him, he too hoped right out. Seizing his hand, while the briny fluid poured in a torrent down his cadaverous cheeks, in a voice hussy with emotion he blubbered out: "We owe to you our preservation and our navy; I cannot thank you enough!" The sight must have been deeply-effecting, and we presume that every man present, especially if he wanted an office, bedewed his handkerchief with tears.
As it is impossible to tell at what time our modern Jeremiah may burst into tears, all who visit the White House should go prepared for contingencies-- Montgomery Advertiser.

div3.head: Whiskey and the soldiers.
div3.p:
--Some time ago, talking with an intelligent soldier who had passed many years in India, and had seen some terrible applications of the "cat-o'-nine-tails," we asked "how many of the czars of flogging had anything to do with drink?
" "Every case," replied the soldier. "I never knew a soldier flogged, except through drink in some way or other, or stealing so as to get drink.
Many a time have I had to help roll barrels of grog up the hill to one of the canteens in India, and it was a common joke to say, "Bill, I wonder how many court martials there are inside here!"
A Seat compliment was paid the other day to a lady, She had just swallowed appetite glass of wine, as a gentleman in company asked for a taste.
It's all gone, " said she, laughingly, unless you will take some from my lips."
"I should be most happy," he replied; "but I never take sugar in mine."

div4.p: I want to engage immediately the services of aman, over 48, compotent to manage alarge estate in King William county, three miles north of my Post-Office, Hanover G. H.

I wish to purchase immediately, an sound, and reliable Horse for a Troops, to meet whose wants I will pay from $300 to $400. It will be useless to offer any horse whose value is less than the sum first named.
I should like to purchase two Sharp's Rifles, to be sent to be sent to Stafford C. H., or Fredericksburg.
Having yet on hand near 400 pairs of Socks, and the present time being unfavorable for distribution, I can receive no more after the 25th inst.

men,

First-rate workmen.

div3.p:

Apply at once to

div3.head: Wanted — Recruits.
div3.p:
--The Varina Artillery, stationed at Haroy's Bluff, on James River, is desirous of filling its ranks to the number of one hundred efficient men, and we earnesily appeal to the citizens of Richmond, Henrico, and the adjoining counties, who are not now in the volunteer service, to unite with us a one in the defence of the most important position on James river.
A bounty of $50, and transportation, will be given to all who report to us at this station.

div3.head: Wanted — Substitutes.
div3.p:
We want Substitutes for friends in the country, and are willing to pay goo prices.
Apply at our office, corner of 13th and Cary streets, up stairs.

div3.head: Wanted--
div3.p: Forty Negroes, To be employed at Tredegar Iron Works; and fifth to sixty to be employed at the Iron Mines, in batetourt county.

Wanted--
Mustard.

12t Main street. mh 20--10t*

div3.head: Wanted.--
div3.p: A Youth, about 15 years of age, desires a situation.

He is active, and can give the best of references.
He will accept of a situation in a store or or in any respectable business.
Address "R.B.," Box 801.

div3.head:
Wanted--
Recruits for
Second Company
Richmond Howitzers.
div3.p:
This Company having reorganized, will receive a limited number of gentlemen to fill up its ranks to the maximum number the law requires.
Those desirous of joining are assured that the previous good character of the company will be fully sustained under its new organization.
None but men of unexceptionable moral character need apply.
Any militiaman who wished to volunteer can do so, and will recieve the usual bounty.
For further information apply to either of the undersigned, at No. 7 Wall street, under St. Charles Hotel.
div3.closer:
H. S. Jones,
R. B. Pleasants,
Or to Geo. L. Christian,
Charles City C. H. Va. mh 19--5t*

--An accurate
Accountant and

div3.head:

Recruits,
div3.p:
For the Third Company Richmond Howitzers — This old and well known company having reorganized under capt. Moseley, few recruits will be received.
A rare opportunity is offered to young men of good character to join this favorite arm of the service.
Persons wishing to enlist, can call upon Lieut Carter, at Kent, Paire & Co.'s; Geo. P. Thaxton, at Wadrworth & Palmer's; R. Channing Price, at T. R. Price &Co.
s; or Wm.S. White, at Tardy & Williams's. The bounty of $50 will be paid on enlisting.

div3.head: Wanted--
div3.p:
Volunteers--Fifty men to complete a company of Heavy Artillery, for Col. Morries's regiment.
This company offers great inducements to these wishing to avoid militia draft, as it will be stationary and in good quarters.
A bounty of $50 will be paid to each man when mustered in. Rations will be furnished those desiring them until mastered in. This is the last opportunity offered the citizens of Henrico, Richmond, Chesterfield and Hanover.
For further information, apply next door to Hicks's Stable 10th street, where one of the undersigned will be found.

div3.head: Wanted
div3.p:
--Forty Recruits, for a first-class Artillery Company.
The Battery and full Equipments for each man are secred.
Term of enlistment, for two years; or for the war. None but good men wanted.
The Battery will be drilled by an experienced officer, and the Recruits properly cared for till mustered into service.
Application enlist be made in person, at the store of D. M. Brotherton, & Co. No, 107 Main st. $50 bounty paid to all recruits.

div3.head:
Wanted — Imidiately,
Recruits,
Recruits,
Recruits.
div3.p: Wanted, immediately, three(300)hundred respectable and able-bodied men, to form an Artillery Battallon, to serve for two years, or during the war.

I have opened a recruiting office in the city of Richmond, on 10th st., bet. Main and cary, under superintendence of Serg. W. Snellibol--Comfortable quarters will be provided board free.
Man will be paid the date of their enlistment.
It is the earliest wish of the undersigned to be ready with the new organization before the form of his present company expires.
He therefore indulges the hops that thos those not now in the service will not be slow in enlisting; for, firht we must, and conquer, too, And, to do so, we must be well-drilled and prepared for our enemies.
Any communications addressed to me at Fredericksburg, will meet with prompt attation.
div3.closer:
R. L. Wlker,
Capt. Com'dg Purcell Artillery.
Whig and Examiner copy for 3--ts

div3.head: Wanted — negro-land
div3.p:
--The James River and Kanawha Company wants to Hire negro Carpenters and Laborers, to work on the repairs of the canal during rthe present year.
Liberal wages will be paid, and rations, clothing, and medicine and medical attendance furnished.
For further informantion address the undersigned, in this city, or see the Company's Agents along the line of the canal, who are authorised to hire.

div3.head: Wanted
div3.p:
--Several Finishers, to work on Engines.
High wages paid.
Also, one man who understands making Cokel from Bituminous Coal.

div3.head: Wanted
div3.p:
-- Five hundred of Cak Bark at the Rivhmond Tennery, on Brook Avanue, for which I will pay 88 per cord; also, for Chesnut and Spanish Cak, and 86 for Red and Black Cak. Having purchased the entire interest in the above Tennery, I shall continue the business on the cash system in my own name.--Persons having Bark or Hides for sale will please call at the Tannery, or address me by mail, stating the quantity and quality or each.
I will pay the highest market prices for Hides and Skins, either green or dry.

closer.salute: I respectfully refer to J. W. Recridge or M. Altmoyor.

div3.head: Wanted--
div3.p:
A steady, industrious man as an
Overseer,
on a farm about five miles west of the city.
Washing for a small family.
Apply, in rear of Mitchell & Tyler's to

div3.head:
Wanted--Fifty
Hatmakers,
div3.p: To whome I offfer the best wages and constan employment.

div3.head: Wanted
div3.p: --$120,000.--$20,000 wanted for one year, secured by mortgage on valuable realestat in Mississippi.

$100,000 wanted for five years or mopre, secured by mortgage on valuable real estate in the State of Louisians.
For particulars apply to.

div3.head: Wanted.
div3.p:
Persons desiring
Substitutes for the War, can find them by application at my office.
div3.closer:
Samuel D. Hicks.
Shockoe Slip. fe 22--lm*

div3.head:
Wanted--
to Hire,
div3.p: For surface operatious, at the Carbon Hill Mine ten able Negroes, from the country.
Also, a trusty and exoperienced Driver, for a farm wagon.

div3.head:
Wanted — Recruits for the
Goochland Grays!
div3.p:
A recruitig office will be opened at Manskin Town, Goochland county.
for the above named company, on the 28th inst. Fifty Dollars bounty and rations allowed from the date of enlistment Under the recent act of the Legislature, this company will be re-organized, February 20th, 1862.
Come one, come all.

div3.head:
Wanted--
Fifty Artillery Recruits,
div3.p: To fill up my company ofLight Artillery.--$50 bounty aid upon enlistment; wages and rations from date of enlistment.
Recruiting office, three doors below Crawford's Salcon, Tenth street:

The War Department preferring all companies of artillery to be deteched, I have declined organizing a battallion.
This will be an answer to the many letters received upon the subject.

div3.head: Wanted--
div3.p:
Patricts awake!
your country calls and needs you.--100 Recruits wanted immmediately for a first-classs infantry company.$50 bounty — Uniforms free, and rations and pay6 from the day of enlistment.
The opportunity will be offered you of electing good offficers, who have been in active service in this war. Apply to
div3.closer:
W.B.Robins,
At Scott's Drug Store, corner of Franklin
and, 17th sts. fe 21--lm*

div3.head:
Wanted — Recruits for the
"Thomas Artillery!"
div3.p:
Capt, Philip B. Stanard, assisted by Sergeants Joseph A. Blair and T. B. McCurdy, will receive the names of all persons wishing to enlist in this Battery.
One of the above named gentlemen may be found during the day, either at the office of the Middlothian Coal Mning Company, on 12th street, between Main and Cary, or that of Mr. E. A. Smith, on Main street, between 20th and 21st.

The service seen by this Battery in too well known to need further notice.
Usual bounty,&, given.

div3.head: Wanted
div3.p:
--Recruits for Theomas Artillery.-- Capt Philip B. Stanard, assisted by Sergeants Jos. A. Blair and T B. McCUSDY, will receive the names of all persons wishing to enlist in this Battery.
One of the above named gentlemen may be found during the day either at the office of the Midlothian Coal Mining Company, on 12th street, between Main and Cary, or that of Mr. E A. Smith, between 20th and 21st.
The service seen by this Battery is too well known to need further notice Usual bounty, &c, given.

div3.head:
Wanted!
wanted!!
wanted!!!
div3.p:
Seventy-five Recruits, for the Governor's Mounted Guard, which companys is now quartered at Manassas, $50 bounty.
Clothing and subsistence will be furnished.
Apply6 at the Recruiting Rendexvous, on Bank street, near the corner of 12th.

div3.head:
Wanted.--
Heavy Artillery.
div3.p:
Recruits wanted to serve in a battallon on James river.
The battallon will be under the command of Maj. Wm. Allen, who has permission from the Secretary of War to raise it.
div3.closer:
miles Selden, office at
Selden & Miller's Cary and 14th sts. fe 25--lm*

div3.head:
Wanted--
Recruits,
div3.p: For a crack regiment — the 4th Alabama, and Law's Legion.

The undersigned, having been appointed recruiting officer for the 4th Alabama Regiment, has opened an office in this city, at 109 Main street,(up stairs,) three doors above 14th, over Mr. W. S. Tupman's Furnishing Store.

This is an opporntunity rarely offered for men desirous to enrol themselves under the basnner of their country, in a regiment which has already won for itself a name for gallantry unsurpassed in history.
The $50 bounty nallowed by Government will be paid upon enrollment in cash.
Clothing, rations, &c, furnished free.
I have given Lewis Warrington and John R. Plater authority to act as recruiting officers with me.
div3.closer:
Mr B. Travis,
Lieut. 4th Alabama Reg't,
Recruiting Officer.
N. B.--Those desiring substitutes for the war, and non-resident parties who desire to serve as substitutes, would do welll to call at our recruiting office. mh 6--8m*

div3.head: Wanted — Gas Fitter.
div3.p: A good Gas Fitter will be given liberal wages and steady emplyment by immediate application to the subscriber.
div3.closer:
G.H. Gangley.
13th street, between Main and Cary. ja 29--ts

div3.head: Wanted
div3.p:
--to Buy — A young Woman, with or without incumbrance, competant and qualified as a house servant.
Apply at corner of 12th and Franklin streets, over Confederate Commissioner's Office.

div3.head: Runaways--$10 Reward
div3.p: --Left the house of Mr. G. A. W. Taylor, on the 19th inst., a negro boy by the name of Jim. (very black.)--He has been seen in the last day or two walking about the streets in company with other boys.--Jim was hired last year to H. T. Cook, Esq. The above reward will be given if lodged in jail or brought to me.
div3.closer:
E. D. Eacho.
14th st., near Exchange Hotel. mh 24--3t

div3.head: Runaway
div3.p:
--$25 Reward.--Left without provocation; about 1st January last, my boy Henry, about 26 years of age, a barber by trade, hired for the present year to Wermer & Co., opposite the American Hotel.
Henry is a spare, brown colored boy, about 5½ feet high, genteel address, wears a small beard, with full head of hair.
He may have hired himself to go with some officer or soldier.
The above reward will be paid for his delivery to me or Mr. Wermer, or any information of his whereabouts, so that I get him.

div3.head: Runaway--$25 Reward
div3.p:
--For John, A Yellow man, tolerably bright, with quite a full head of hair, inclined to be very bushy.
He went to the 2d Market with my cart on the 17th of March, and left the cart in the street and has not since been seen or heard from.
I will give the above reward if taken, in this State and $50 if taken in any other State.
John is quite intelligent and very polite.
He is about 28 to 30 years old, and has a small scar on one of his hands.
He was dressed with blue homespun pants, and dark overcoat, and drab-colored felt hat, when he left.
He was hired by me of Wm. N. Yarbour, adm'r of Jesse Yarbour dec'd, of Hanover.
I will pay the above reward and all expensed if delivered to me in Richmond or lodged in jail so that I get him again.

div3.head: Ranaway
div3.p:
--$200 Reward — From the residence of the subscriber, on the 30th Nov. negro boy Isaac, about 30 years old, 5½ feet high, ginger-bread complexion, of pleasant and polite manners, hair short and nappy, and is left handed.
I will give the above reward for the apprehension and delivery of said boy in the jail at Orange C. H.

This negro ran off in consequence of having committed a most brutal and unprovoked murder upon the person of my overseer, and it behooves the community at large to be on the look-out for this criminal.
He may be in the vicinity of Fredericksburg, where he has acquaintances.

div3.head:
Headq'rs Dep't of Henrico,
Richmond, Va.March 21, 1862.
div3.p:
General Orders.
No. 11.--

Agencies for the obtaining of substitutes are forbidden under such penalties as may be imposed by a court martial.
When such agencies are employed, both the principal and the substitute will be impressed into the military service, and the money paid for the substitute will be confiscated by the Government.
div3.closer:
By order of
John H. Winder,
Brigadier General Commanding, &c.
L. R. Page,
A. A. General. mh 22--1w

div3.head:
Substitutes!
Substitutes!!
div3.p: Three abis substitutes may be had by immediate application, by letter or otherwise, to "G. F. C," Norfolk, Va. Persons in want will state what service and what they will pay.Norfolk, March 19, 1862.

div3.head:
Heavy Artillery--
attention
Substitutes.
div3.p:
By authority of the Governor of Virginia to raise a Company of Heavy Artillery (to be part of Virginia's quota.) I will receive twenty substitutes this day, if of irreproachable character.
None others need apply.--Office at the corner of Franklin and 12th sts.
